title: How was England in the 19th century? - Quora

response.answer_text: Split between the wealthy and the very poor, the educated and uneducated. There was overcrowding in the cities, many families living under one roof. Lots of grime and fog from the chimneys and factories. Lots of menial work. Labourers, miners (men, women, children and animals), factories, mills, farms. For the less fortunate the workhouses. Healthcare was poor, operations horrific. Lots of new technology and inventions. Lots of crime too. Harsh punishments. Beautiful countryside, lovely mansions and castles. Wars, we have always been involved in wars. Poor human rights, but developing.

In the 19th Century it was a relatively peaceful time only being in 2 wars, ( one they got beat in ) they're empire saw great expansion and power. Timber was heavy used by the iron and steel shipbuilding industry. Living in London in the 19th Century wasn't too good tho especially in the Very late years if you were a women. While the city did grow economical and population wise, overcrowding started to become a big problem and a large percentage of the population of London started to live in poverty and slums were bigging to pop up everywhere, and as you know this was the heart of the industrial revolution and the 19th Century was an era of rapidly acceleration in scientific discovery and ivension. People such as Alexander Graham Bell who invented the famous telephone and the graphahpone where from the UK or Scotlan if you want to say that. The world in the 19th Century was filled with exploration and discovery.
